## Why is it important? {.smaller}

<div style="margin-bottom: 50px;"></div>

- Overturning of Roe v. Wade (2022) as pivotal moment
- Paradox: Stable public opinion vs heightened political salience

<div style="margin-bottom: 50px;"></div>

### Theoretical Puzzle {.smaller}
- Persistent stability in abortion attitudes vs:
  - Evolving views on other issues (same-sex marriage, cannabis) (Adamczyk et al., 2020)
  - Growing affective polarization (Iyengar et al., 2019; Iyengar et al., 2012)
  - Emergence of lifestyle politics (DellaPosta et al., 2015)

---

## Literature Review {.smaller transition=none}
### Classic Determinants  

- **Religious Factors** (Jelen & Wilcox, 2003; Cook, 2019)  
  - **Affiliation**: Denominational differences (Catholic/Protestant vs Jewish/mainline)  
  - **Religiosity**: Outweighs affiliation differences (Lynxwiler, 1999; Wilcox, 1992)  

- **Socioeconomic Variables** 
  - **Education & Income**: Socioeconomic privilege → abortion rights support (Granberg & Granberg, 1980)  
  
- **Political Alignment** 
  - **Partisan sorting**: Liberal/Democrat vs. Conservative/Republican (Hess & Rueb, 2005)  
  - **Bidirectional relationship**: Abortion attitudes drive party switching (e.g., 1992 pro-choice Republicans; Abramowitz, 1995)

## Literature Review {.smaller}
### Emerging Determinants: Lifestyle Politics?  

<div style="margin-bottom: 50px;"></div>

- **Consumption as Identity** 
  - Prius (urban/progressive) vs. Pickup (rural/conservative) polarization  

- **Cultural Sorting**  (DelaPosta et al., 2015)
  - Leisure activities (craft beer vs hunting) signal ideological alignment  

- **Affective Reinforcement**  
  - Lifestyle habits crystallize group boundaries

## Methodology {.smaller transition=none}
### Interaction Analysis

<div style="margin-bottom: 50px;"></div>

For each significant interaction, we calculated:

<div style="margin-bottom: 100px;"></div>

$$\Delta_{effect} = |\beta_{classic \times lifestyle} - \beta_{classic}|$$

## Conclusion {.smaller}

::: {.incremental}
1. **Traditional factors remain strong predictors, but...**
2. **Interaction patterns revealed nuanced attitude formation processes**
2. **Lifestyle factors seem to modify the effects of classic predictors**
:::

## Discussion {.smaller}
### Limitations
- Non-causal correlational design  
- Binary abortion measure  
- Sample size constraints
